config.text: You have stopped in an emergency area. What must you do before you rejoin the carriageway?

choices.label: Use the emergency telephone
Give an arm signal as you are moving off
Switch on your vehicle's headlights
Move away with your hazard lights on

correct.text: To rejoin the carriageway from an emergency area, you must use the emergency telephone and follow the operator's advice. A lane may have to be closed so that you can rejoin the carriageway safely.

incorrect.text: To rejoin the carriageway from an emergency area, you must use the emergency telephone and follow the operator's advice. A lane may have to be closed so that you can rejoin the carriageway safely.

config.text: You're on a three-lane motorway. Which lane are you in if there are red reflective studs on your left and white ones to your right?

choices.label: In the right-hand lane
In the middle lane
On the hard shoulder
In the left-hand lane

correct.text:
The colours of the reflective studs on the motorway and their locations are
  • red – between the hard shoulder and the carriageway
  • white – between lanes
  • amber – between the carriageway and the central reservation
  • green – along slip-road exits and entrances
  • bright green/yellow – at roadworks and contraflow systems.

incorrect.text:
The colours of the reflective studs on the motorway and their locations are
  • red – between the hard shoulder and the carriageway
  • white – between lanes
  • amber – between the carriageway and the central reservation
  • green – along slip-road exits and entrances
  • bright green/yellow – at roadworks and contraflow systems.

config.text: Some two-way roads are divided into three lanes. Why are they particularly dangerous?

choices.label: Traffic in both directions can use the middle lane to overtake
Traffic can travel faster in poor weather conditions
Traffic can overtake on the left
Traffic uses the middle lane for emergencies only

correct.text: If you intend to overtake, you must consider that approaching traffic could be planning the same manoeuvre. When you've considered the situation and decided it's safe, indicate your intentions early. This will show the approaching traffic that you intend to pull out.

incorrect.text: If you intend to overtake, you must consider that approaching traffic could be planning the same manoeuvre. When you've considered the situation and decided it's safe, indicate your intentions early. This will show the approaching traffic that you intend to pull out.

config.text: You're driving in town. Why should you be careful if there's a bus at a bus stop on the other side of the road?

choices.label: The bus might have broken down
Pedestrians might come from behind the bus
The bus might move off suddenly
The bus might remain stationary

correct.text: If you see a bus ahead, watch out for pedestrians. They might not be able to see you if they’re behind the bus.

incorrect.text: If you see a bus ahead, watch out for pedestrians. They might not be able to see you if they’re behind the bus.

meta.xref: DES s7, HC r25, KYTS p145

config.text: Which type of crossing allows cyclists to ride across with pedestrians?

choices.label: Toucan
Puffin
Pelican
Zebra

correct.text: A toucan crossing is designed to allow pedestrians and cyclists to cross at the same time. Look out for cyclists approaching the crossing at speed.

incorrect.text: A toucan crossing is designed to allow pedestrians and cyclists to cross at the same time. Look out for cyclists approaching the crossing at speed.

config.text: What can you do to reduce environmental damage caused by your vehicle?

choices.label: Avoid using the cruise control
Use the air conditioning whenever you drive
Use the gears to slow the vehicle
Avoid making a lot of short journeys

correct.text: Avoid using your car for short journeys. On a short journey, the engine is unlikely to warm up fully and will therefore be running less efficiently. This will result in the car using more fuel and emitting higher levels of harmful emissions.

incorrect.text: Avoid using your car for short journeys. On a short journey, the engine is unlikely to warm up fully and will therefore be running less efficiently. This will result in the car using more fuel and emitting higher levels of harmful emissions.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC p127, KYTS p9

config.text: What messages are given by circular traffic signs that have a blue background?

choices.label: They give temporary directions during a diversion
They give directions to car parks
They give motorway information
They give mandatory instructions

correct.text: Signs with blue circles generally give mandatory instruction. These are often found in urban areas and include signs for mini-roundabouts and directional arrows.

incorrect.text: Signs with blue circles generally give mandatory instruction. These are often found in urban areas and include signs for mini-roundabouts and directional arrows.

config.text: When would you use the right-hand lane on a three-lane motorway?

choices.label: When you're turning right
When you're overtaking
When you're travelling above the speed limit
When you're trying to save fuel

correct.text: The right-hand lane of the motorway is for overtaking. Sometimes you may be directed into a right-hand lane as a result of roadworks or a traffic incident. This will be indicated by signs or officers directing the traffic.

incorrect.text: The right-hand lane of the motorway is for overtaking. Sometimes you may be directed into a right-hand lane as a result of roadworks or a traffic incident. This will be indicated by signs or officers directing the traffic.

config.text: What type of vehicle displays this yellow sign?

choices.label: A broken-down vehicle
A school bus
An ice-cream van
A private ambulance

correct.text: Buses which carry children to and from school may stop at places other than scheduled bus stops. Be aware that they might pull over at any time to allow children to get on or off. This will normally be when traffic is heavy during rush hour.

incorrect.text: Buses which carry children to and from school may stop at places other than scheduled bus stops. Be aware that they might pull over at any time to allow children to get on or off. This will normally be when traffic is heavy during rush hour.

config.text: You’re waiting at a pelican crossing. What does it mean when the red light changes to flashing amber?

choices.label: Give way to pedestrians on the crossing
Move off immediately without any hesitation
Wait for the green light before moving off
Get ready and go when the continuous amber light shows

correct.text: This light allows pedestrians already on the crossing to get to the other side in their own time, without being rushed. Don’t rev your engine or start to move off while they’re still crossing.

incorrect.text: This light allows pedestrians already on the crossing to get to the other side in their own time, without being rushed. Don’t rev your engine or start to move off while they’re still crossing.

config.text: What should you check before you start a journey in foggy weather?

choices.label: The radiator has enough anti-freeze
You have a warning triangle in the vehicle
The windows and lights are clean and clear
You have a mobile phone with you

correct.text: If you have to drive in fog, switch your dipped headlights on and keep all your windows clear. You should always be able to pull up within the distance you can see ahead.

incorrect.text: If you have to drive in fog, switch your dipped headlights on and keep all your windows clear. You should always be able to pull up within the distance you can see ahead.

config.text: What could you do to help injured people at an incident?

choices.label: Keep them warm and comfortable
Give them something to eat
Keep them on the move by walking them around
Give them a warm drink

correct.text: There are a number of things you can do to help, even without expert training. Be aware of further danger from other traffic and fire; make sure the area is safe. People may be in shock. Don't give them anything to eat or drink. Keep them warm and comfortable and reassure them. Don't move injured people unless there's a risk of further danger.

incorrect.text: There are a number of things you can do to help, even without expert training. Be aware of further danger from other traffic and fire; make sure the area is safe. People may be in shock. Don't give them anything to eat or drink. Keep them warm and comfortable and reassure them. Don't move injured people unless there's a risk of further danger.

config.text: What signal should you give when you're going straight ahead at a roundabout?

choices.label: Signal left before leaving the roundabout
Don't signal at any time
Signal right when you're approaching the roundabout
Signal left when you're approaching the roundabout

correct.text: When going straight ahead at a roundabout, don’t signal as you approach it. Signal left just after passing the exit before the one you wish to take.

incorrect.text: When going straight ahead at a roundabout, don’t signal as you approach it. Signal left just after passing the exit before the one you wish to take.

config.text: Why should you allow extra room while overtaking a motorcyclist on a windy day?

choices.label: The rider may turn off suddenly to get out of the wind
The rider may be blown in front of you
The rider may stop suddenly
The rider may be travelling faster than normal

correct.text: If you’re driving in high winds, be aware that the conditions might make a motorcyclist (or cyclist) swerve or wobble. Take this into consideration if you’re following or wish to overtake a two-wheeled vehicle.

incorrect.text: If you’re driving in high winds, be aware that the conditions might make a motorcyclist (or cyclist) swerve or wobble. Take this into consideration if you’re following or wish to overtake a two-wheeled vehicle.

config.text: What safety device must be fitted to a trailer braking system?

choices.label: Stabiliser
Jockey wheel
Corner steadies
Breakaway cable

correct.text: In the event that the trailer becomes detached from the towing vehicle, the breakaway cable activates the trailer brakes before snapping. This allows the towing vehicle to get free of the trailer and out of danger.

incorrect.text: In the event that the trailer becomes detached from the towing vehicle, the breakaway cable activates the trailer brakes before snapping. This allows the towing vehicle to get free of the trailer and out of danger.

config.text: When may you stop on a clearway?

choices.label: Never
When it's busy
In the rush hour
During daylight hours

correct.text: Clearways are in place so that traffic can flow without the obstruction of parked vehicles. Just one parked vehicle can cause an obstruction for all other traffic. You mustn't stop where a clearway is in force, not even to pick up or set down passengers.

incorrect.text: Clearways are in place so that traffic can flow without the obstruction of parked vehicles. Just one parked vehicle can cause an obstruction for all other traffic. You mustn't stop where a clearway is in force, not even to pick up or set down passengers.

config.text: What should you do when you're passing loose sheep on the road?

choices.label: Briefly sound your horn
Go very slowly
Pass quickly but quietly
Herd them to the side of the road

correct.text: Slow down and be ready to stop if you see animals in the road ahead. Animals are easily frightened by noise and vehicles passing too close to them. Stop if you're signalled to do so by the person in charge.

incorrect.text: Slow down and be ready to stop if you see animals in the road ahead. Animals are easily frightened by noise and vehicles passing too close to them. Stop if you're signalled to do so by the person in charge.

config.text: How will your journey be affected by travelling outside the busy times of day?

choices.label: Your journey will use more fuel
Your journey will take longer
Your journey will be more hazardous
Your journey will have fewer delays

correct.text: If possible, avoid the early morning, late afternoon and early evening ‘rush hour’. Doing this should allow you to have a better journey, with fewer delays. This should help you to arrive at your destination feeling less stressed.

incorrect.text: If possible, avoid the early morning, late afternoon and early evening ‘rush hour’. Doing this should allow you to have a better journey, with fewer delays. This should help you to arrive at your destination feeling less stressed.

config.text: What's the main cause of skidding?

choices.label: The weather
The driver
The vehicle
The road

correct.text: Skidding is usually caused by driver error. You should always adjust your driving to take account of the road and weather conditions.

incorrect.text: Skidding is usually caused by driver error. You should always adjust your driving to take account of the road and weather conditions.

meta.xref: DES s3, DES s11, DES s15, DES s16, HC r116

config.text: When are you allowed to use hazard warning lights?

choices.label: When stopped and temporarily obstructing traffic
When travelling during darkness without headlights
When parked on double yellow lines to visit a shop
When travelling slowly because you're lost

correct.text:
You mustn't use hazard warning lights while moving, except to warn traffic behind when you slow suddenly on a motorway or unrestricted dual carriageway.
Never use hazard warning lights to excuse dangerous or illegal parking.

incorrect.text:
You mustn't use hazard warning lights while moving, except to warn traffic behind when you slow suddenly on a motorway or unrestricted dual carriageway.
Never use hazard warning lights to excuse dangerous or illegal parking.

config.text: Who is authorised to signal you to stop?

choices.label: A motorcyclist
A pedestrian
A police officer
A bus driver

correct.text: You must obey signals to stop given by police and traffic officers, traffic wardens and school crossing patrols. Failure to do so is an offence and could lead to prosecution.

incorrect.text: You must obey signals to stop given by police and traffic officers, traffic wardens and school crossing patrols. Failure to do so is an offence and could lead to prosecution.

config.text: What does this traffic sign mean?

choices.label: Compulsory maximum speed limit
Advisory maximum speed limit
Compulsory minimum speed limit
Advised separation distance

correct.text: The sign gives you an early warning of a speed restriction. If you're travelling at a higher speed, slow down in good time. You could come across queuing traffic due to roadworks or a temporary obstruction.

incorrect.text: The sign gives you an early warning of a speed restriction. If you're travelling at a higher speed, slow down in good time. You could come across queuing traffic due to roadworks or a temporary obstruction.

meta.xref: DES s6, DES s10, KYTS p26

config.text: What type of vehicle could you expect to meet in the middle of the road?

choices.label: Lorry
Bicycle
Car
Motorcycle

correct.text: The highest point of the bridge is in the centre, so a large vehicle might have to move to the centre of the road to have enough room to pass safely under the bridge.

incorrect.text: The highest point of the bridge is in the centre, so a large vehicle might have to move to the centre of the road to have enough room to pass safely under the bridge.

config.text: What must you do when you're overtaking a car at night?

choices.label: Flash your headlights before overtaking
Select a higher gear
Switch your headlights to main beam before overtaking
Make sure you don't dazzle other road users

correct.text: To prevent your headlights from dazzling the driver of the car in front, wait until you’ve passed them before switching to main beam.

incorrect.text: To prevent your headlights from dazzling the driver of the car in front, wait until you’ve passed them before switching to main beam.

config.text: Why should you switch your headlights on when it first starts to get dark?

choices.label: To make your dials easier to see
So others can see you more easily
So that you blend in with other drivers
Because the street lights are lit

correct.text: Your headlights and tail lights help others on the road to see you. It may be necessary to turn on your headlights during the day if visibility is reduced; for example, due to heavy rain. In these conditions, the light might fade before the street lights are timed to switch on. Be seen to be safe.

incorrect.text: Your headlights and tail lights help others on the road to see you. It may be necessary to turn on your headlights during the day if visibility is reduced; for example, due to heavy rain. In these conditions, the light might fade before the street lights are timed to switch on. Be seen to be safe.

meta.xref: DES s10, HC r186, HC r215

config.text: You're approaching a roundabout. What should you do if there are horses being ridden in front of you?

choices.label: Sound your horn as a warning
Treat them like any other vehicle
Give them plenty of room
Accelerate past as quickly as possible

correct.text: Horse riders often keep to the outside of the roundabout even if they're turning right. Give them plenty of room and remember that they may have to cross lanes of traffic.

incorrect.text: Horse riders often keep to the outside of the roundabout even if they're turning right. Give them plenty of room and remember that they may have to cross lanes of traffic.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC p129, KYTS p12

config.text: What does this sign mean?

choices.label: Side winds
Road noise
Airport
Adverse camber

correct.text: A warning sign with a picture of a windsock indicates that there may be strong side winds. This sign is often found on exposed roads.

incorrect.text: A warning sign with a picture of a windsock indicates that there may be strong side winds. This sign is often found on exposed roads.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC p127, KYTS p64

config.text: Which sign means 'no stopping'?

correct.text: Stopping where this clearway restriction applies is likely to cause congestion. Allow the traffic to flow by obeying the signs.

incorrect.text: Stopping where this clearway restriction applies is likely to cause congestion. Allow the traffic to flow by obeying the signs.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC p126, KYTS p19

config.text: What does this sign mean?

choices.label: Bend to the right
Road on the right closed
No traffic from the right
No right turn

correct.text: The 'no right turn' sign may be used to warn road users that there's a 'no entry' prohibition on a road to the right ahead.

incorrect.text: The 'no right turn' sign may be used to warn road users that there's a 'no entry' prohibition on a road to the right ahead.

config.text: You're waiting to turn right out of a minor road. It's clear to the left but a lorry is coming from the right. Why should you wait, even if you have enough time to turn?

choices.label: Anything overtaking the lorry will be hidden from view
The lorry could suddenly speed up
The lorry might be slowing down
The load on the lorry might be unstable

correct.text: Large vehicles can hide other vehicles that are overtaking – especially motorcycles. You need to be aware of the possibility of hidden vehicles and not assume that it's safe to turn.

incorrect.text: Large vehicles can hide other vehicles that are overtaking – especially motorcycles. You need to be aware of the possibility of hidden vehicles and not assume that it's safe to turn.

config.text: Why should you be cautious when going past this bus waiting at a bus stop?

choices.label: There's a zebra crossing ahead
There are driveways on the left
People may cross the road in front of it
The road surface will be slippery

correct.text: A bus at a bus stop can hide pedestrians who might try to cross the road just in front of it. Drive at a speed that will enable you to respond safely if you have to.

incorrect.text: A bus at a bus stop can hide pedestrians who might try to cross the road just in front of it. Drive at a speed that will enable you to respond safely if you have to.

meta.xref: DES s5, DES s12, HC r231

config.text: How can you avoid wheelspin when you're driving on an icy road?

choices.label: Drive at a slow speed in the highest gear possible
Use the parking brake if the wheels start to slip
Brake gently and repeatedly
Drive in a low gear at all times

correct.text: If you’re travelling on an icy road, extra caution will be required to avoid loss of control. Keeping your speed down and using the highest gear possible will reduce the risk of the tyres losing their grip on this slippery surface.

incorrect.text: If you’re travelling on an icy road, extra caution will be required to avoid loss of control. Keeping your speed down and using the highest gear possible will reduce the risk of the tyres losing their grip on this slippery surface.

config.text: You're driving your car. When may you use a hand-held mobile phone?

choices.label: When you're receiving a call
When you've parked safely
When you're driving at less than 30 mph
When your car has automatic transmission

correct.text: It's illegal to use a hand-held mobile phone while you're driving, except in a genuine emergency. Even using a hands-free kit can distract your attention. Park in a safe and convenient place before receiving or making a call or using text messaging. Then you'll also be free to take notes or refer to papers.

incorrect.text: It's illegal to use a hand-held mobile phone while you're driving, except in a genuine emergency. Even using a hands-free kit can distract your attention. Park in a safe and convenient place before receiving or making a call or using text messaging. Then you'll also be free to take notes or refer to papers.

meta.xref: DES s7, DES s10, DES s11, HC r126

config.text: You're in a line of traffic. What action should you take if the driver behind is following very closely?

choices.label: Ignore the driver behind and continue to travel within the speed limit
Slow down, gradually increasing the gap between you and the vehicle in front
Signal left and wave the driver behind to come past
Move over to a position just left of the centre line of the road

correct.text: If the driver behind is following too closely, there’s a danger they’ll collide with the back of your vehicle if you stop suddenly. You can reduce this risk by slowing down and increasing the safety margin in front of you. This reduces the chance that you’ll have to stop suddenly and allows you to spread your braking over a greater distance. This is an example of defensive driving.

incorrect.text: If the driver behind is following too closely, there’s a danger they’ll collide with the back of your vehicle if you stop suddenly. You can reduce this risk by slowing down and increasing the safety margin in front of you. This reduces the chance that you’ll have to stop suddenly and allows you to spread your braking over a greater distance. This is an example of defensive driving.

config.text: There's been a collision. A motorcyclist is lying injured and unconscious. Why should you only remove their helmet if it's essential?

choices.label: They might not want you to remove it
Removing it could make any injuries worse
Removing it could let them get cold
You could scratch the helmet as you remove it

correct.text: When someone is injured, any movement that isn't absolutely necessary should be avoided, since it could make the injuries worse. Unless it's essential to remove a motorcyclist's helmet, it's generally safer to leave it in place.

incorrect.text: When someone is injured, any movement that isn't absolutely necessary should be avoided, since it could make the injuries worse. Unless it's essential to remove a motorcyclist's helmet, it's generally safer to leave it in place.

config.text: When will a new car need its first MOT test?

choices.label: When it's one year old
When it's three years old
When it's five years old
When it's seven years old

correct.text: The vehicle you drive must be roadworthy and in good condition. If it's over three years old, it must pass an MOT test to remain in use on the road (unless it's exempt from the MOT test – see GOV.UK).

incorrect.text: The vehicle you drive must be roadworthy and in good condition. If it's over three years old, it must pass an MOT test to remain in use on the road (unless it's exempt from the MOT test – see GOV.UK).

config.text: When should tyre pressures be checked?

choices.label: After any lengthy journey
After travelling at high speed
When tyres are hot
When tyres are cold

correct.text: Check the tyre pressures when the tyres are cold. This will give you a more accurate reading. The heat generated on a long journey will raise the pressure inside the tyre.

incorrect.text: Check the tyre pressures when the tyres are cold. This will give you a more accurate reading. The heat generated on a long journey will raise the pressure inside the tyre.

config.text: What should you do to avoid fuel spillage?

choices.label: Check that your tank is only three-quarters full
Check that you've used a locking filler cap
Check that your fuel gauge is working
Check that your filler cap is securely fastened

correct.text: When learning to drive, it's a good idea to practise filling your car with fuel. Ask your instructor if you can use a petrol station and fill the fuel tank yourself. You need to know where the filler cap is on the car you're driving, so you know which side of the pump to park at. Take care not to overfill the tank and make sure you secure the filler cap correctly, so that no fuel leaks onto the road while you're driving.

incorrect.text: When learning to drive, it's a good idea to practise filling your car with fuel. Ask your instructor if you can use a petrol station and fill the fuel tank yourself. You need to know where the filler cap is on the car you're driving, so you know which side of the pump to park at. Take care not to overfill the tank and make sure you secure the filler cap correctly, so that no fuel leaks onto the road while you're driving.

config.text: Why should you never wave people across at pedestrian crossings?

choices.label: Another vehicle may be coming
They may not be looking
It's safer for you to carry on
They may not be ready to cross

correct.text: If people are waiting to use a pedestrian crossing, slow down and be prepared to stop. Don't wave them across the road, because another driver may not have seen them, may not have seen your signal, and may not be able to stop safely.

incorrect.text: If people are waiting to use a pedestrian crossing, slow down and be prepared to stop. Don't wave them across the road, because another driver may not have seen them, may not have seen your signal, and may not be able to stop safely.

config.text: You're driving in a slow-moving queue of traffic. What should you do just before changing lane?

choices.label: Sound the horn and flash your lights
Look for motorcyclists filtering through the traffic
Give a ‘slowing down’ arm signal
Change down to first gear

correct.text: In queuing traffic, motorcyclists could be passing you on either side. Use your mirrors and check your blind area before changing lanes or changing direction.

incorrect.text: In queuing traffic, motorcyclists could be passing you on either side. Use your mirrors and check your blind area before changing lanes or changing direction.

config.text: How should you drive when you're driving along a road that has road humps?

choices.label: Maintain a reduced speed throughout
Accelerate quickly between the humps
Always keep to the maximum legal speed
Drive slowly at school times only

correct.text: Road humps are there for a reason – to protect vulnerable road users by reducing the speed of traffic. Don’t accelerate harshly between the humps. Put the safety of others first and maintain a reduced speed throughout the zone.

incorrect.text: Road humps are there for a reason – to protect vulnerable road users by reducing the speed of traffic. Don’t accelerate harshly between the humps. Put the safety of others first and maintain a reduced speed throughout the zone.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC p126, KYTS p16

config.text: What must you do when you see this sign?

choices.label: Stop only if traffic is approaching
Stop even if the road is clear
Stop only if children are waiting to cross
Stop only if a red light is showing

correct.text: 'Stop' signs are situated at junctions where visibility is restricted or where there's heavy traffic. They must be obeyed: you must stop. Look carefully before moving off.

incorrect.text: 'Stop' signs are situated at junctions where visibility is restricted or where there's heavy traffic. They must be obeyed: you must stop. Look carefully before moving off.

config.text: You're on a motorway. What does it mean if a red cross is showing above the hard shoulder and mandatory speed limits above all other lanes?

choices.label: The hard shoulder can be used as a rest area if you feel tired
The hard shoulder is for emergency or breakdown use only
The hard shoulder can be used as a normal running lane
The hard shoulder has a speed limit of 50 mph

correct.text: A red cross above the hard shoulder shows that it's closed as a running lane and should only be used for emergencies or breakdowns. On some motorways, the hard shoulder may be used as a running lane at busy times. This will be shown by a mandatory speed limit on the gantry above the hard shoulder.

incorrect.text: A red cross above the hard shoulder shows that it's closed as a running lane and should only be used for emergencies or breakdowns. On some motorways, the hard shoulder may be used as a running lane at busy times. This will be shown by a mandatory speed limit on the gantry above the hard shoulder.

config.text: Why do MOT tests include an exhaust emission test?

choices.label: To recover the cost of expensive garage equipment
To help protect the environment against pollution
To discover which fuel supplier is used the most
To make sure diesel and petrol engines emit the same fumes

correct.text: Emission tests are carried out to make sure your vehicle’s engine is operating efficiently. This ensures the pollution produced by the engine is kept to a minimum. If your vehicle isn't serviced regularly, it may fail the MOT emissions test.

incorrect.text: Emission tests are carried out to make sure your vehicle’s engine is operating efficiently. This ensures the pollution produced by the engine is kept to a minimum. If your vehicle isn't serviced regularly, it may fail the MOT emissions test.

config.text: How does drinking alcohol affect your driving behaviour?

choices.label: It improves judgement skills
It increases confidence
It leads to faster reactions
It increases concentration

correct.text: Alcohol can increase confidence to a point where your driving behaviour might become ‘out of character’. Sensible behaviour might change to risk-taking behaviour. Never let yourself or your friends get into this situation.

incorrect.text: Alcohol can increase confidence to a point where your driving behaviour might become ‘out of character’. Sensible behaviour might change to risk-taking behaviour. Never let yourself or your friends get into this situation.

config.text: What will be affected if the road surface becomes soft in very hot weather?

choices.label: The suspension
The exhaust emissions
The fuel consumption
The tyre grip

correct.text: If the road surface becomes very hot, it can soften. Tyres are unable to grip a soft surface as well as they can a firm dry one. Take care when cornering and braking.

incorrect.text: If the road surface becomes very hot, it can soften. Tyres are unable to grip a soft surface as well as they can a firm dry one. Take care when cornering and braking.

config.text: You're travelling behind a bus. What should you do if it pulls up at a bus stop?

choices.label: Accelerate past the bus
Look for pedestrians
Sound your horn
Pull in closely behind the bus

correct.text:
People may be running to catch the bus or passengers leaving the bus might wish to cross the road in front of the bus. Look out for them if you intend to go past it. Consider how many people are waiting to get on the bus – check the queue if you can. The bus might move off straight away if no-one is waiting to get on.
If a bus is signalling to pull out, give it priority if it’s safe to do so.

incorrect.text:
People may be running to catch the bus or passengers leaving the bus might wish to cross the road in front of the bus. Look out for them if you intend to go past it. Consider how many people are waiting to get on the bus – check the queue if you can. The bus might move off straight away if no-one is waiting to get on.
If a bus is signalling to pull out, give it priority if it’s safe to do so.

questions.text: Why has the bus driver positioned the bus on the left?

choices.label: In case the pedestrian wants to get on the bus
The bus needs extra room to get around the roundabout
The sign on the roundabout is directing traffic to 'keep left'
To get a better view of the roundabout

correct.text:
A long vehicle at a roundabout may need to use the left-hand lane, even if it's signalling to go right. This is because it needs extra room to travel around a roundabout. For the same reason, it may also straddle lanes.
Watch out for a long vehicle's signals and allow it plenty of room on a roundabout.

incorrect.text:
A long vehicle at a roundabout may need to use the left-hand lane, even if it's signalling to go right. This is because it needs extra room to travel around a roundabout. For the same reason, it may also straddle lanes.
Watch out for a long vehicle's signals and allow it plenty of room on a roundabout.

questions.text: Why does the cyclist take the longer route around the roundabout?

choices.label: The cyclist is riding into a one-way street
It's easier to give arm signals while you're on the left
Cyclists may keep to the left for safety
To avoid being dazzled by the sun

correct.text:
Roundabouts can be dangerous places for cyclists. To stay safe, they may keep to the outside of a roundabout. They may cycle in the left lane, even if they intend to turn right.
Watch out for a cyclist's arm signals, as they'll tell you the direction they intend to take. Always give cyclists plenty of room.

incorrect.text:
Roundabouts can be dangerous places for cyclists. To stay safe, they may keep to the outside of a roundabout. They may cycle in the left lane, even if they intend to turn right.
Watch out for a cyclist's arm signals, as they'll tell you the direction they intend to take. Always give cyclists plenty of room.

meta.xref: HC r238, HC p135, KYTS p45

questions.text: What do the yellow lines along the edge of the road mean?

choices.label: They are rumble strips
They mark the edge of the road
Pedestrians shouldn't cross where there are yellow lines
No waiting

correct.text:
A double yellow line at the edge of the road means no waiting at any time.
This means that you can't wait or park. However, you may stop on double yellow lines to drop off or pick up people. You may also stop to load or unload, provided there are no loading restrictions.

incorrect.text:
A double yellow line at the edge of the road means no waiting at any time.
This means that you can't wait or park. However, you may stop on double yellow lines to drop off or pick up people. You may also stop to load or unload, provided there are no loading restrictions.
